questiontext.text:
An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 4.7 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 333 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 8 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=9.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 2000 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=76:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
In order to find the crack length at failure, rearrange the Griffiths Formula to make $$l$$ the subject as follows:

$$l=\left(\left(\frac{\sigma \:_c}{\sigma \:_o}-1\right)\cdot \:0.5\right)^2\cdot r$$

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  333 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  4.7 MPa; and $$r$$ = 8$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 4.7 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 9.8 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 151325 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:
HINT

Use the Griffiths Formula (or Stress Raiser equation) to answer the first part of the question:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  349 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  4.2 MPa; and $$r$$ = 7$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 4.2 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 11.8 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 189838 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

questiontext.text:
An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 4.8 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 446 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 7 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=14.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 2600 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=56:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #11).

An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 2.8 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 321 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 3 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=9.7:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 2300 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=185:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #20).

generalfeedback.text:
In order to find the crack length at failure, rearrange the Griffiths Formula to make $$l$$ the subject as follows:

$$l=\left(\left(\frac{\sigma \:_c}{\sigma \:_o}-1\right)\cdot \:0.5\right)^2\cdot r$$

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  321 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  2.8 MPa; and $$r$$ = 3$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 2.8 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 9.7 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 426340 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:
HINT

Use the Griffiths Formula (or Stress Raiser equation) to answer the first part of the question:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  453 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  4.6 MPa; and $$r$$ = 6$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 4.6 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 14.3 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 158491 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

questiontext.text:
An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 3.8 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 311 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 5 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=8.2:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 1300 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=178:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #30).

An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 3.3 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 465 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 3 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=14.7:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 2500 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=123:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #39).

generalfeedback.text:
In order to find the crack length at failure, rearrange the Griffiths Formula to make $$l$$ the subject as follows:

$$l=\left(\left(\frac{\sigma \:_c}{\sigma \:_o}-1\right)\cdot \:0.5\right)^2\cdot r$$

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  465 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  3.3 MPa; and $$r$$ = 3$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 3.3 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 14.7 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 308023 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:
HINT

Use the Griffiths Formula (or Stress Raiser equation) to answer the first part of the question:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

$$l=\left(\left(\frac{\sigma \:_c}{\sigma \:_o}-1\right)\cdot \:0.5\right)^2\cdot r$$

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  447 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  5 MPa; and $$r$$ = 4$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 5 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 7.8 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 133366 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:
HINT

Use the Griffiths Formula (or Stress Raiser equation) to answer the first part of the question:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

questiontext.text:
An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 4.2 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 374 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 5 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=9.7:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 2600 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=73:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #49).

An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 4 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 390 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 6 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=14:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 1600 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=131:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #58).

generalfeedback.text:
In order to find the crack length at failure, rearrange the Griffiths Formula to make $$l$$ the subject as follows:

$$l=\left(\left(\frac{\sigma \:_c}{\sigma \:_o}-1\right)\cdot \:0.5\right)^2\cdot r$$

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  390 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  4 MPa; and $$r$$ = 6$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 4 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 14 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 209575 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:
HINT

Use the Griffiths Formula (or Stress Raiser equation) to answer the first part of the question:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  497 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  3.5 MPa; and $$r$$ = 5$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 3.5 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 24.9 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 274594 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

questiontext.text:
An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 4.4 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 332 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 5 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=6.9:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 1700 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=101:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #68).

An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 4.2 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 408 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 9 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=20.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 2600 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=73:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #77).

generalfeedback.text:
In order to find the crack length at failure, rearrange the Griffiths Formula to make $$l$$ the subject as follows:

$$l=\left(\left(\frac{\sigma \:_c}{\sigma \:_o}-1\right)\cdot \:0.5\right)^2\cdot r$$

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  408 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  4.2 MPa; and $$r$$ = 9$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 4.2 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 20.8 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 190540 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:
HINT

Use the Griffiths Formula (or Stress Raiser equation) to answer the first part of the question:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

$$l=\left(\left(\frac{\sigma \:_c}{\sigma \:_o}-1\right)\cdot \:0.5\right)^2\cdot r$$

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  500 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  3 MPa; and $$r$$ = 5$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 3 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 34.3 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 374170 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:
HINT

Use the Griffiths Formula (or Stress Raiser equation) to answer the first part of the question:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.

questiontext.text:
An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 2.5 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 328 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 5 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=21.2:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 1300 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=414:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #87).

An athlete breaks her leg in an accident and has a bone plate fitted, as shown in the radiograph below.


Analysis of the radiograph reveals a 0.1 mm long crack in the woman's bone plate.

The tensile loading on the plate at right angles to the plane of the crack cycles between 0 and 2.5 MPa with each step she takes.

Suppose the fracture stress of the bone plate material is 488 MPa and the radius of the crack tip is 3 $$\small\mu$$m throughout.

How long will the crack be when the plate fails?

(Give your answer in mm to 1.d.p.)

{1:NUMERICAL:=28.3:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

She takes, on average, 2600 steps each day. The rate of crack growth is given by:

$$\frac{da}{dN}=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot a^2\$$

Where: $$a$$ = crack length; $$N$$ = number of loading cycles; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = the difference between the minimum and maximum nominal stress on the plate at right angles to the crack; and $$C$$ = a constant, of value 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1 for the current situation.

Ignoring the impact of any bone healing, how long will it be before the plate fails?

(Give your answer in days to the nearest whole number)

{1:NUMERICAL:=207:0.5#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Question ID #96).

generalfeedback.text:
In order to find the crack length at failure, rearrange the Griffiths Formula to make $$l$$ the subject as follows:

$$l=\left(\left(\frac{\sigma \:_c}{\sigma \:_o}-1\right)\cdot \:0.5\right)^2\cdot r$$

In this case: $$\small\sigma _c$$ =  488 MPa; $$\small\sigma _o$$ =  2.5 MPa; and $$r$$ = 3$$\small\mu$$m


By rearranging the equation given in the question, and integrating between the limits of the initial crack length $$(_{a_i})$$ and crack length at failure $$(_{a_f})$$, the following expression can be produced:

$$N=C\cdot \left(\Delta \sigma _o\right)^2\cdot \pi ^2\cdot \left[-a^{-1}\right]_{a_i}^{a_f}$$

In this case: $$C$$ = 3 x 10-16 Pa-2.m-1; $$\small\Delta \sigma _o$$ = 2.5 MPa; $$_{a_f}$$ = 28.3 mm; and $$_{a_i}$$ = 0.1 mm.

This gives a value of $$N$$ = 538469 (the number of steps before the plate fails).

hint.text:
HINT

Use the Griffiths Formula (or Stress Raiser equation) to answer the first part of the question:

$$\sigma _c=\sigma _o\cdot \left(1+2\cdot \sqrt{\frac{l}{r}}\right)$$

Where: $$\small\sigma _c$$ = the stress at the tip of the crack; $$\small\sigma _o$$ = the nominal stress distant from the crack; $$l$$ = the the length of the surface crack; and $$r$$ = the crack tip radius.

To answer the second part of the question, you will need to integrate the equation given in the question, and evaluate it between the limits of the inital crack length, and crack length at plate failure.
